body:
Form Builder uses input names to identify each input in your service. 

Input names are not shown to users. They're used just by the editor to refer to other inputs.

## Example

Let's say you want to only display a particular page to a user based on the answer they gave in a radio list on an earlier page.

When setting the [conditional logic](/validation) on the later page, you'll need to refer back to the radio list from the earlier page.

To do that, you'll use the input name of the radio list, usually combined with the [option value](/option-value) of a specific answer in the list.

Input names:

- can use letters, numbers, hyphens and underscores - no spaces or special characters
- correspond to the HTML ‘name’ attribute

## Repeatable components

If you're creating repeatable components, just name the [input name](/input-names) once, without a number.

For example, if a user can 'Add another child', your input name for that repeatable component would be simply 'child'. 

Form Builder will add numbers to each repeatable component automatically.

## IDs

Form Builder also uses IDs. 

Form Builder creates these automatically, so you don't need to worry about them.

IDs are unique identifiers that Form Builder needs to recognise each item, component and page in your service.
heading: Input names
